title: 115_hr2687
content: The Act is titled the "Medicaid Coverage for Addiction Recovery Expansion Act" and allows states to provide medical assistance for residential addiction treatment facility services. It also modifies the IMD exclusion. The Social Security Act is amended to include residential addiction treatment facility services for individuals with substance use disorders as part of a full continuum of evidence-based treatment services under the State plan. The Social Security Act is amended to include residential addiction treatment facility services for individuals with substance use disorders as part of a full continuum of evidence-based treatment services under the State plan. The term 'residential addiction treatment facility services' refers to inpatient services provided for treating a substance use disorder for up to 2 consecutive periods of 30 days each, with assessment and progression through the clinical continuum of care required. The State agency must ensure that residential addiction treatment facilities are accredited by recognized organizations to provide necessary treatment and support services for individuals with substance use disorders. In a fiscal year, a residential addiction treatment facility must not exceed an average of 40 beds used for providing services. Federal financial assistance for medical services during a 30-day period of receiving treatment at the facility does not affect eligibility. Pregnant women receiving residential addiction treatment can remain eligible for services for additional 30-day periods. The amendments made by this section allow pregnant women receiving residential addiction treatment to continue receiving services for additional 30-day periods based on medical necessity related to substance use disorder and its impact on birth outcomes, effective January 1, 2019. GRANT PROGRAM TO EXPAND YOUTH ADDICTION TREATMENT FACILITIES UNDER MEDICAID AND CHIP. The Secretary will award grants to States to expand infrastructure and treatment capabilities of youth addiction treatment facilities for Medicaid or CHIP beneficiaries under 21 in underserved communities. Grant funds can be used for existing facility improvements but not for new construction or medical assistance. The Secretary will award grants to States for expanding infrastructure and treatment capabilities of youth addiction treatment facilities for Medicaid or CHIP beneficiaries under 21 in underserved communities. States must submit detailed information on the types of infrastructure and treatment capacity they plan to fund under the grant program. Grants will be awarded within 1 year of the enactment of the Act and will last for a maximum of 5 years. Under the grant program, eligible youth addiction treatment facilities funded must prioritize services for Medicaid or CHIP beneficiaries under 21 in communities with high numbers of medically underserved at-risk youth. Additionally, not less than 15 percent of the grant amount awarded to a State must be used for facilities in rural areas. The grant program funds addiction treatment facilities prioritizing services for Medicaid or CHIP beneficiaries under 21 in communities with at-risk youth. Eligible facilities must be in rural areas or target Medicaid/CHIP beneficiaries in rural areas. Definitions include addiction treatment services, CHIP, and eligible youth addiction treatment facility. The curr_chunk discusses the definitions of terms related to Medicaid, CHIP beneficiaries, and medically underserved populations. Medicaid refers to the medical assistance program under title XIX of the Social Security Act. CHIP beneficiaries are individuals enrolled in the State Medicaid plan or State child health plan. Medically underserved populations are defined as per the Public Health Service Act. The curr_chunk authorizes $50,000,000 for the provisions of this section under the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
